docs.lead_paragraph: The Dutch financial services company ING Group N.V. said today that it had reached agreement with the United States health care company Aetna Inc. to buy two units. ING will pay $5 billion in cash and will assume $2.7 billion of outstanding debt for the units: Aetna Financial Services and Aetna International.

headline.main: ING Agrees to Buy 2 Aetna Units

docs.abstract: ING Group NV will pay $5 billion in cash and will assume $2.7 billion of outstanding debt for Aetna units Aetna Financial Services and Aetna International (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: For 10 days now, Arab residents of East Jerusalem have followed the reports from Camp David with rising anticipation -- and anxiety. For the first time in 33 years, it appears, Israel has signaled a willingness to give up some control of the Arab neighborhoods it annexed here after the 1967 Middle East war.

headline.main: Jerusalem Arabs Look Expectantly and Anxiously to Camp David

docs.abstract: Arabs of East Jerusalem follow reports from Camp David summit with anticipation and anxiety, as well as quiet ambivalence about radical political and economic change if status of Jerusalem is altered; photo; Christian Arabs are alarmed by reports that control of Christian sites is also under discussion; three patriarchs of major Christian churches issue unusual joint protest against any division (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Vice President Al Gore blew into Gov. George W. Bush's home territory today to try to undercut the governor's popularity, suggesting that Mr. Bush's priorities were skewed and had made Texas a backwater where big oil interests are more important than children's health. ''Now, this is a wonderful state,'' Mr. Gore said. ''But I think it should be -- and I think most people agree -- it should be a state where it's just as easy to raise a child as it is to set up an oil rig.''

headline.main: Gore, on Rival's Home Turf, Says Bush Is Soft on Big Oil

docs.abstract: Vice Pres Al Gore blows into Gov George W Bush's home territory, suggesting that Bush has skewed priorities that have made Texas into backwater where big oil interests are more important than children's health; Bush responds; photo of Tore at earlier stop in Cedar Rapids, Iowa (M)
docs.snippet: Vice President Al Gore blew into Gov. George W. Bush's home territory today to try to undercut the governor's popularity, suggesting that Mr. Bush's priorities were skewed and had made Texas a backwater where big oil interests are more important than...

docs.lead_paragraph: For months, Vice President Al Gore and other national Democrats have depicted George W. Bush's Texas as all but a third-world country. Pollution? Mr. Gore says Texas is the most polluted state in America. Poverty? Mr. Gore says that too many of Texas' people are poor and that the state does too little for them. Mr. Gore even came to Texas today to continue the criticism, questioning Mr. Bush's handling of the state budget and his priorities as governor. Lagging schools, children without health insurance, pockets of disease -- Mr. Gore's ever-expanding list of Texas woe leaves out mosquitoes and big hair, but it does go on.

headline.main: With Gore Jabbing at Bush, Texas Takes It on the Chin

docs.abstract: Vice Pres Gore's criticisms of social and environmental conditions in Texas, home state of his presidential rival, prickle Texans, who have long believed that outsiders do not understand their outsized state and never will; several declare themselves Proud of Texas Committee to defend honor of state, although news release fails to mention that four of five members are also supporters of Gov George W Bush; Texans discuss stereotypes old and new (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Aetna Inc. has agreed to sell its international and financial services units to the ING Group of the Netherlands for $5 billion in cash, people close to the deal said last night. Under the deal, which ING planned to announce before the opening of the stock markets in Europe today, Aetna will create a new health care company that will keep the name Aetna. Aetna's shareholders will receive $35 in cash and one share of the new company in exchange for each share of the old Aetna. ING will also assume $2.7 billion of Aetna's long-term debt.

headline.main: Aetna to Sell Its International and Financial Services Units

docs.abstract: Aetna Inc agrees to sell its international and financial services units to ING Group for $5 billion in cash; Aetna will create new health care company that will keep name Aetna; ING will also assume $2.7 billion of Aetna's long-term debt; plans to operate its growing US financial business from its existing headquarters in Atlanta; agrees to maintain number of Aetna employees at close to current levels, with future reductions mainly from attrition as employees retire or leave (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: NEW YORK MANHATTAN: BUILDING COMPLAINT LINE The New York City Department of Buildings has opened a special telephone line for complaints about crumbling facades and other potentially dangerous building conditions. The system, which centralizes information for buildings in all boroughs into one center, allows callers to register complaints and gain access to a site's history of violations. Complaints will be forwarded to inspectors who, according to a department spokesman, Paul Wein, are ''ready to be dispatched immediately.'' The number is (212) 227-7000. Stacy Albin (NYT)

Albright. A1

docs.lead_paragraph: In a case that could have broad impact on health insurance coverage of contraceptives nationwide, Planned Parenthood yesterday filed a class-action lawsuit charging that a company whose insurance plan covers most prescription drugs but excludes contraceptives is illegally discriminating against its female employees. ''It's sex discrimination when male employees get their basic health care needs covered by insurance but women are forced to pay for their own,'' said Gloria Feldt, president of the Planned Parenthood Federation of America.

headline.main: Company's Insurance Should Pay for Contraceptives, Suit Says

docs.abstract: Planned Parenthood Federation of America, in case that could have broad impact on health insurance coverage of contraceptives nationwide, files class-action suit charging company whose insurance plan covers most prescription drugs except contraceptives illegally discriminates against female workers; sues Bartell Drug Co on behalf of Jennifer Erickson and company's other female workers; Erickson, pharmacist, notes she must frequently tell customers that their plans do not cover contraceptives; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: A July 13 letter writer suggests ways to ''ease the financial burden of health expenditures that our graying Americans bear.'' He sensibly recommends generic drugs, which are already widely used.
docs.abstract: Marvin J Schissel letter comments on July 13 letter on ways of easing financial burden of health expenditures on aging Americans (S)
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    A July 13 letter writer suggests ways to ''ease the financial burden of health expenditures that our graying Americans bear.'' He sensibly recommends generic drugs, which are already widely used.

docs.lead_paragraph: It's the wealthiest families in America, a few thousand, who would benefit most from the estate tax repeal for which the Republican Congress just voted -- with the support of Gov. George W. Bush -- as well as from the massive income tax cut that Mr. Bush has proposed. But is it worth it, given the inevitable public backlash over awarding hundreds of billions of dollars to those who need it the least? As a Republican, I ask my party: Is it worth it to be known increasingly as protector of the rich and powerful, despite the appreciative response in campaign contributions?
docs.abstract: Larry Rockefeller Op-Ed article warns Republican Congress and Gov George W Bush risk placing Republican Party outside mainstream with tax cuts for rich, other policies; urges mainstream Republicans to act independently in this year's elections (M)
